nodes.bodyText: In that specific case, a simple concatenation should be more efficient. What do you think?
Introduce a version without supplier: there is no reason to create a supplier here, a simple String is OK as there is no parameters
I don't understand why you change this.

Very sorry about that, it looks like I miss-merged this file. Thank God for PR's!

@lcosson: I think there is no reason to use a supplier here.
I think it may be because lambda only allows final constants. Maybe with double[]? Not sure if it is equivalent, performance wise.
I miss something during my first review.
@lcosson: I think there is no reason to use a supplier here.
@lcosson I think there is no reason to create a Supplier here
Are you sure they are public?

I think adding a check for log level enabled before a call with string constants does not offer performance improvement, the log library will do the same check in the implementation (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8788096/log-info-using-log-isinfoenabled). Personally I prefer removing the check for such one-line calls, to improve readability.
I see your point, but then it's like for the partial use of Suppliers with @mathbagu : what's the policy ? Should we say "prefer doing stuff that way in general" or "work on a case by case basis" ?

Looking to the code of logback, the log methods use a chain of filter to define to decide if a LogEvent has to be created. There are two different implementation of LogFilter, and in that case, the TurboFilter are used. These filters have to be really fast. So I think, we can follow Luma's advice.
Only impact on raising the error level for test is that we may reduce the coverage of some code.
